Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Postdoctoral Research Fellowship award to Dr. David Kikuchi is supported by both the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Office of International Science and Engineering at the National Science Foundation. During the 24-month fellowship, Dr. Kikuchi will work on a project titled, "Optimal learning and the evolution of Batesian mimicry" under the sponsorship of Prof. Thomas Sherratt at Carleton University in Ottawa, Canada, and Prof. Johanna Mappes at the University of Jyväskylä, Finland.

The goal of this project is to evaluate how the costs of acquiring information about an animal's environment influence its behavior. Currently, little is known about this process because most theories assume that animals have perfect knowledge of their environments (or at least cannot improve their information). New models of optimal animal foraging behavior will be built using computer simulations. Those models will then be tested in a "novel world" environment where wild birds learn about prey that they have never encountered before. This work is important because learning is a universal problem that animals face; it can be an expensive process, and a better understanding is needed of how the value of information dictates how much is learned.

Dr. Kikuchi will work with undergraduate students who will be trained with both computer simulations and field work. This project will also foster international collaboration between Carleton University and the Center of Excellence in Biological Interactions in Jyväskylä. Results of this work will be presented to the public, during events such as Darwin Day, or in ScienceNOW that has previously highlighted Dr. Kikuchi's work.

This award provides a unique opportunity for a US scientist to collaborate with foreign scientists, and utilize the unique facilities, expertise and experimental conditions available abroad.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. David Kikuchi was supported by a Postdoctoral Research Fellowship from both the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Office of International Science and Engineering at the National Science Foundation. Dr. Kikuchi’s project, “Optimal learning and the evolution of Batesian mimicry” was done over two years in Ottawa, Canada, and Jyväskylä, Finland. This fostered collaboration with international colleagues in two different countries outside the United States.

 

The goal of this project was to develop new theory about how animals manage the so-called exploration-exploitation trade-off when they are foraging on potentially dangerous prey. The trade-off is between the risks an animal takes to learn about its prey before deciding that it has gathered enough information about it. In Ottawa, Dr. Kikuchi applied decision theory to this problem to figure out a solution for when predators should categorize two apparently different kinds of prey as separate or not.

 

Once the new theory had been devised, Dr. Kikuchi travelled to Finland to test it in a laboratory setting known as a “novel world.” In the novel world, birds that were captured (temporarily) from the wild were given unfamiliar prey items. To gain food, they had to learn to discriminate between these prey items. However, some prey items were distasteful, so learning came at a cost. Therefore, the novel world made an ideal system to test the theory about how animals resolve exploration-exploitation trade-offs. In fact, results showed that although birds were sensitive to different levels of costs, costs did not always change how they discriminated between prey. Birds are very curious, and curiosity often trumps caution! Current ongoing collaborations between Dr. Kikuchi and colleagues in Canada and Finland are aimed at understanding how best to test the theory in experiments.

 

In addition to the major goals of developing new theory and testing it, Dr. Kikuchi participated in several other studies during his time under NSF sponsorship. Those projects included experimental tests of other theories, experimental applications of cognitive psychology to foraging behavior, and studying natural selection on prey species in the wild. Furthermore, Dr. Kikuchi mentored two undergraduate honors students who undertook research projects with him in Ottawa. Results of all the work done on this grant was presented at major international conferences including the meeting of the International Society for Behavioral Ecology in New York, and the meeting of the Society for the Study of Evolution in Sao Paulo, Brazil. In addition, they were published in peer-reviewed journals such as Evolution and The American Naturalist. This award provided a unique opportunity for a US scientist to collaborate with foreign scientists, and utilize the unique facilities, expertise and experimental conditions available abroad.
